text.p: Danish shipbuilding and shipping group J.Lauritzen said it finalised on Tuesday the sale of 48 percent of its Danyard unit to Malaysia's Penang Shipbuilding Construction SDN BHD (PSC), although the deal remained subject to the approval of Malaysian authorities.
As announced last December, when the two sides signed a letter of intent, the purchase price is $100 million.
In a statement on Tuesday, however, Lauritzen said that the sum could be revised up or down depending on the result of a pending independent evaluation of Danyard's activities.

Danyard said that it expected Malaysian authorities to approve the sale within the next two to three months and for PSC shareholders to give their blessing by the end of August 1997, at which time payment would be completed.

The statement said that Danyard was in preliminary negotiations to build four chemical tankers for the Norwegian-U.S. Stolt group and was also part of a consortium tendering to build six ocean patrol vessels for the Malaysian government.
Danyard has suffered heavy losses in recent years due to stiff competition, adverse currency movments and productivity problems.

The deal with PSC includes a commitment to improve productivity and, Danyard says, improves the yard's competitiveness in Asia. Executives say that the strengthening U.S. dollar has also worked in its favour.
